comments.commentBody: And in Britain, David Cameron continues to push his own austerity and says it is “working” and that he will bravely carry on--even as the economy falls into recession once again.  (I listen to the BBC a lot).

I fear it's worse than that, Walter. Those who put forth the bad ideas do so knowing full well they're bad, and why. Their allegiance isn't to those who put them in office but, rather, those who paid them to do their bidding.Those who believe those bad ideas are good, do so in complete ignorance of their implications, and in the futile hope that they'll be trickled upon. The old saying, "there are none so blind as those who will not see," is as true today as the day it was coined.
I agree.  A picture, or in this case a graph, is worth a 1,000 words.  Links!  More links to primary sources for the masses!

On the column, I miss the charts that so effectively make your points on the blog. I miss the extra links to blooming, buzzing details that go into your conclusions, often oversimplified by your critics who argue without rigorous logic and subtlety.

I do note two types of comments: those buried in technical jargon, drawing crazy connections, wired without a fine sense of balance and proportion. Not trolls. but drones. The other is the balance sheet type who thinks that the accounting approach governs national economies, never recognizing that a family doesn't fire itself when it cuts its budget but businesses do.

I have learned from you to read research reports.The federal reserves work is insightful, esp, the global farm reports out of Kansas City's fed, Cleveland's midwest report, and Atlanta and Dallas' excellent work. Why is no mention made in MSM of the rich lode of ideas and research from bright young minds and their non-partisan examing of key ideas. The San Francisco Fed agrees with you that govt budget restraints are retarding growth, with Europe's debt crisis and austerity. Yet on CSPAN, I see Jim DeMint (my senator!) ask about low saving rates. What do the unemployed have to save?

I see Mitt talking about jobs but not understanding an economy. His marching orders are a foundation of sinking sand. I see corporations willing to rip the country apart for profits that sit offshore. Right now, many put greed first, promise prosperity, but believe in bad ideas.
Do burning a train and killing 50 innocent people is right?

It doesn't wash! Mr Modi is complicit in the horrendous mass violence by Hindus against Muslims in Gujarat in 2002. Just look at some of the speeches he made during that time and his poisonous rhetoric against Muslims at various points in time. The mass violence was orchestrated by Hindu extremist groups after the Godhra incident with the tacit support of the BJP led state government.

I dont understand why politicians have to show "emotions" as a proof of good behavior, good policies or good legislation of any kind. I dont think any politician is elected to show sentiments, that's what actors are there for. Modi showed his remorse by developing Gujarat making it the most efficiently and effectively managed state with a reduction in public corruption of government officials. Hows that for an apology. Would a "sorry" served a Muslim in Gujarat of better economic conditions that his present and next generation will enjoy because of what Modi did. Is the Muslims not using the Modi built roads? Or is he not drinking the water from the Modi built reservoirs. I have very little respect for people who show crocodile tears and do nothing for the people who have elected them with great hope. I think Modi's greatest apology is in economic and social developments that he has brought to the people of not only his state but to whole of India. Dont forget, poor states do get subsidized from the taxes individuals and companies in Gujarat pay to the central government. So stop singing the same song past its expiry date. Congress and its cronies have to think a better strategy than asking for an apology, as if that's what will change the world and India.

Who should be saying sorry ? He who saved the situation or those who started the carnage in Sabarmati. And he has a point. Will you absolve him and condone so many deaths just because he says sorry. Like you have done so with our Saradarji saying sorry for Sikh massacre. Are you aware of the plight of the sikh families whose beloved ones died and who are still looking for the closure. No my friend. It is all very easy to state things academically and move on. Real life is more complicated.
Strange! Even if we believe him, why can't he say sorry for the riots and what happened? 1000 people were massacred and someone can't say sorry, doesn't have the grace to apologize!

The influx of Muslim population of Bangladesh since 1971 had made local population a minority. Indira Gandhi and her son Rajiv and now his wife Sonia have taken advantage this vote bank and ignored local s. The current in India is like a Moghul era only interested in local resources and not people!!

“India will build more infrastructure in the next three to four decades than it has in the past 5,000 years,” said Mr. Kant.

I have a message for Mr Kant and people like him. Stop making empty useless statements, and learn to make statements with your actions. Thank you!

You should be. For it is equally depressing for us to know that there are fellow Indians who are lead by propoganda, have no sense of right or wrong, have no sense of applying a yardstick equally to all, and they go ballistic with their outbursts.

Where were you when MMS said that "The first priority for the resources of this country belongs to minority"

Where were you When the Muslim Hyderabad MP warned of radicalization of Muslims?

I find it utterly depresssing that so manyof my fellow Indians are prepared to rally behind a man like Modi. Reading the interview you realise the guy does not have an iota of remorse for what happened. (here is a good story on this topic by the NYT columnist Manu Joseph: http://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/16/world/asia/16iht-letter16.html)

I would say to Modi: first apologise publicly for what happened, show remorse that innocent people were killed. Even if you were not directly responsible (and i am sure he was) you were in charge then and the events happened under your watch. If you were unable to put a stop to the carnage or you didnt know about it, you were simply incompetent. If you knew about it and didnt try to stop it, you need to be severely punished.

Then refute the Praveen Togadias of this world, the communal parties such as RSS and Bajrang Dal. These are Hindu fanatics who seem to live a couple of centuries ago. For someone who likes to paint himself as a moderniser ,these are not the kinds of friends you ought to have.Afffirm your commitment to a modern, multi-cultural, multi-faith India that respects the rights of all minorities and women. I MIGHT then be willing to give you a chance.

Those purple orchids are disgusting. Color sense, people?
Find a good designer, for heaven's sake. It's the swearing-in of India's president. Genda phool? Lotuses? Warm-colored lilies? Even roses would have done.

The problem dates back to the 80's with Indra Gandhi using migrants from Bangladesh as a voting block to retain power in Assam. She was responsible for much of divisive politics we see in India today.

Tragedy in Assam is not communal, its economical. If you don't examine the problem correctly you are bound to prescribe the wrong medicine. Oh and Hindu blood is cheap in India, didn't you know? Its cheap because Hindus don't vote as a monolith. Without vote power you cant expect any real power.

SM,
I have family from Assam, and nobody is happy being invaded by illegal Bangladeshi Muslim immigrants. Certainly the problem is communal -- but the crooked Left won't recognize the possibility of Muslims being communal.

Please stop using Godhar riot for personal gratification. Nobody is shading a drop of tear for mascaring going on in Asam or anywhere in the world. Politics and news media are important pillars of soceity and both of them has been used improperly.

It is called Godhara riot? what is Godhara riot?.... If those innocent carsevaks had not been burn alive there could not be any riots. What was the fault of those car sevaks?

Can any government take control of riots within one day?

Second, it has been more than 5 years, why Modi has not been convicted yet? Is it this kind of polics need to be played?

Is Governer of Colorado responsible for Masscare in a theater in subrb of Denver?

If Modi is responsible for Godhar riot for failing to keep the situation in control, So does the current Assam Government for the current masacare of Hindus in Assam. But, look at a tragedy!
Central Govt Minister said that do not compare Assam with Gujarat. Why Hindus blood is cheap?
Have you considered relocating?

Looking out over the next four years and beyond, there is little hope of fixing what needs fixing without electing blue houses of Congress, turning state houses blue, and getting the money out of politics. For now, the right wing GOP is fixated on the non-Anglo-Saxon in the White House. Who knows what it is they'll be fixated on in four years? They won't relent until they either implode or, G-d Forbid, they win.

Janet,

Burying A.C. power lines wastes energy. The electricity leaks into the ground and accidents happen. I don't think your other ideas are much better Utah is not going to turn into a "Blue State" anytime soon.

A great way to use all that money people are willing to lend to the government at -0.6% interest would be to begin a massive project to bury all power lines. Given that climatologists are predicting more frequent and more intense storms, such a project would be wise. It would also create a lot of jobs in every state. And that is the reason Republicans will never support it.

We need to remove from office all the people who have refused for the past two years to vote for legislation that would finance infrastructure projects. Such people, including my senators Orrin Hatch and Mike Lee, as well as my representative Jim Matheson, a blue dog Democrat, have betrayed our country and should not be in office.

I agree - luck, mood or something...  I only had one of those!  No JK Home Run for me; in fact I was thrown out between second and third.  Just too many words I didn't know, mixed with phrases that escaped me.
Gee, I found it harder.  Which made it all the more satisfying!  EPISTEMOLOGICAL was a gimme, but PASTORAL EPISTLE eluded me for a very long time.

This seemed to me easier than the usual Friday puzzle; the long words just seemed to drop into place and create the frame for the whole.   Luck or mood or something plays an interesting role in solving these things.  Surprised that "epistemological" and "pastoral epistle" turn out to be the same length . . . .

Mr. Douthat, you are erroneously conflating support for gun control with seeking to ban guns. And while I don't dispute that there are some progressives who want to ban guns, the vast majority of us do not seek to do so.

Instead, I would venture that most progressives think that additional steps need to be taken to reduce the "dangers posed by allowing the reckless and the careless to own and carry weapons." We believe that mandatory background checks, closing the gun show loophole, banning cop-killer bullets and bullet clips that hold 100 shells, making it easier for police to trace guns that are used in a crime and to revoke the licenses of corrupt gun dealers, and making sure people on the terrorist watch list cannot buy guns are all common sense steps to protect public safety while not infringing on the right to own a gun that the Supreme Court found in the 2nd Amendment.

Unfortunately, such commonsense regulation is stymied by the NRA, which refuses to accept that with rights come responsibilities. As such, the NRA prevents action to protect public safety, while at the same time falsely accusing even the mildest supporters of common sense gun control of being out to take away everyone's guns.

In short, guns aren't the problem - the NRA is the problem. We need to overcome the NRA so that we can have a serious conversation about gun rights and safety.

http://www.winningprogressive.org

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Winning-Progressive/195682780442236

Holding contradictory thoughts for some people results in their remaining together but separate, for others it results in the merger of the thoughts into something new.  On the other hand, characterizing an event consisting of contests by contrasting the unity of the event as a whole with a notion of agon itself is clever.  I like the architecture of the ideas here, but the brief for competition and dominance sounds to me too much like a request for affirmation of a worldview that plays to the author's strengths and preferences.  Or maybe I misread it; maybe David likes to dance, too?  Watching David Broder dance at the wedding of one of his sons left an impression on me that Washington journalists can be quite good at it.

The Colorado gun violence, just ahead the elections, did present a rare opportunity to contemplate a strict and well regulated gun control regime, while also to make it an important electoral issue to be debated publicly; alas but, the opportunity was squandered by both the contenders for presidency, probably under strong pressures from the gun lobby. It was also the moment to ponder over the spirit of the second amendment, and present an expansive interpretation of it, that too was lost in the din of electioneering.

Mr. Brooks, you are correct when you opine that politics should not be monomaniacal.   And it is fair to say that you occasionally bow toward the center in your writing, as you do in this column.  All of which makes it all the more disappointing and frustrating when you embrace, as you inevitably do, the increasingly rigid stands of today's Republican Party.  Perhaps one day, you'll surprise your readers acknowledge, for example, that markets can be imperfect and that government can play a useful role in societal betterment.

This is wonderful news about the successful removal of the Elwha dam and the rapid restoration of the river.  There are many dams in the West that need to be removed, including the Glen Canyon Dam on the Colorado River.  The Elwha success will make it easier to argue for the removal of these dams as well.

David,

The Government can print money they don't need to keep cash on hand like normal people ( a family or private business). Collecting too much in taxes past what you spend is bad for the economy too. It has the opposite effect of the Feds policy of Quantitative easing. Interest rates are low here because people around the world invest here. You had better hope that remains the case too. If we were paying the same high interest rates as Spain we would be in trouble.

Richard, you didn't read the column.

"And it’s not just America. At this point, every advanced country that borrows in its own currency is able to borrow very cheaply."

Japan, for example, has debt over 200% of GDP and lower rates than the US.

The last time we had high interest rates was when Nixon tried to freeze prices. the result was a spike in rates that peaked just as Carter took office. Of course Carter got the blame for that.

Then there are the gold bugs. they will tell you the way to beat inflation is to buy gold. the problem with gold is it does not pay any interest, it costs to store, and it can lose value. Most of you do not remember when the Krugerrand was the buy of the day. Gold went from $125 and ounce to $800, then tanked. Gold does follow inflation as it has recently, but notice it is down from its peak.

As long as the U.S. can make good on its debt, its bonds will be bought at low interest rates. There is a core of people who want to eliminate the Fed as they blame these low rates on it. However as long as demand for loans are low, savings rates will remain low.

As for the government having no debt, then it will show a surplus, and taxpayers will demand a refund which leaves the government with no emergency funds. For the government to operate efficiently, it has to borrow. But when it borrows as it did to finance the invasion and occupation of Iraq, that will have to be paid for, and the only way to do so is by taxes. That debt was wasted money that can not be recovered.

Debt to finance public expenditures gets returned from the benefits it brings such as better roads, clean air and water, and even keeping some businesses solvent which keeps people working.

Bad example: should the tax payers and insurers really be paying for Viagra at all? It is just an entertainment product, and complaining that it is 20$ a pill is like complaining that DVDs are so expensive that Congress should reform copyright law to allow pirated downloads.
The arguments that have some moral high ground when we are talking about access to anti-seizure medication don't apply to this one.
What is interesting with Viagra though is that even without generics, there are competing products like Cialis that do basically the same thing. But they do not seem to compete on the basis of cost.
SOLUTES was my undoing, since I rarely seek help, especially for non-Naticks.
Couldn't manage without Ms. Check... still fun and I almost always encounter new words - like SOLATES

Thought that looked like a lot of white space, but didn't know it was a record.

Stared at all that empty space and ventured a few words here and there, and finally got a toehold in the SE corner. Added a few longer entries (had to throw out ACT OF THE APOSTLE, among others) and finally had it down to GEREN_, MA_ON_O, and _UNES.

Knew it had to be MA_ONTO but had SOLUTES instead of of SOLATES; Ms. Check got me on the right track.

Took me a long time - didn't seem like it would come together until the end - a very fine puzzle.

adam

What's really disgusting is seeing these smiling faces while gorging on what's been killed - flaunting it. Once I was invited to a wedding dinner where we were served tiny hearts, livers - whatever from some tiny bird. wasn't I lucky to NOT have to eat that because I didn't/don't eat meat. I had a delicious veggie quiche; the other guests were quite jealous! Eating animals and wearing pelts of animals - that's suppose to be avant garde?

I recently worked some summer races at one of the world's greatest speedways as a flagman. I was stationed at a small area with some grass and low shrubs and some electrical boxes. I soon discovered that there was a very nice brown rat scurrying about whom I quickly dubbed "Carrera D. Raton". Each week I shared scraps of my meal with him/her and also left small cans with water, as it has been a dry summer here in the Carolinas. Recently he/she disappeared, but has been replaced by several smaller examples who also appreciated my largesse. I love rodents of all sizes and would never deliberately hurt one of them.

Shame! These doofuses couldn't even use NYC subway rats! To so lamely fail the locavore test!

Personally I prefer the rural rodents that proliferate in the fields a few miles from the beaches of Goa, that subtle vein of cumin and cardamom touched with sea salt that runs through their sinews so that grilled on coals of sandalwood they taste naturally curried.

Poor Harold Rosenberg! The silly boy thought art could never go the way of the circus. In his grave, he spineth like a toupee.

I doubt that rats are tasty. Otherwise, we would have seen recipes of different ways of prepare rats passed down through the generations!

But surely a true NY artist would eat and serve Manhattan (Greenwich Village) born and bred Bohemian Rats rather than farm/Lab raised or "pasteurized" CA Rats. In fact, why not organize a little pre-dinner hunting party of sorts to work up an appetite!
In the wonderful British series Allo Allo, the mother character says "in the last war, we used to eat cats." I don't want to eat rats or cats, by choice or desperation.

This idea should not be discarded.  As much as we Americans may find the idea disgusting, we should take a closer look at this potential food source.   With a rapidly growing population of 7 billion people on this planet, we do need to consider alternative and additional sources of food that do not have a severe impact on the planet.   Pork and beef both consume vast resources in their production and cause unending pollution.   There is no shortage of rats, they easily reproduce, and farming them should, I would guess, involve a much lower impact to the environment.
